data.text:
Let me briefly tell you about this absolute banger of a cyber security story fresh off the press in Poland.

Since 2022, rail companies in Poland struggled with broken trains — all by the same manufacturer, Newag. The trains would either fail to start on their own, or couldn’t be turned on again after periodic servicing at rival companies. This caused chaos for everyone involved; caused timetable changes, delays and all sorts of inconvenience for passengers and rail companies alike.

At some point, a question arose of whether the manufacturer might somehow be responsible. Newag were fast to counter argue that other servicing companies were simply not as good at their job — after all, all the Newag trains serviced by Newag themselves were working fine. (Worth noting that those state contracts for train servicing are very lucrative, and in the past, dominated by Newag.)

Time passed and the situation of Newag’s rival train servicing companies became dire. One in particular — STS — even started accruing penalty charges from one of the rail companies for being late with servicing. Again, it was suggested that maybe they didn’t quite know what they were doing (while Newag did, of course).
